Comment: It's pretty unusual for a single, narrow piece of legislation to move successfully through the process by itself. Bills on similar topics almost always get combined into a single piece of legislation, typically by the chair of the committee with jurisdiction over the issue. Is that what you're talking about?  And it's not about credit. If some Congressperson's legislation gets included as a title of a broader bill, everybody still knows that it came from the original sponsor.

Comment: Oooh I can actually answer this!  A big part of it is resources. Party leadership positions get bigger staff budgets and more staff and as such, can spare the people to work on writing legislation more often. It's actually a pretty big endeavour to write a bill believe it or not, and not every congressperson has the time or the staff to create legislation all on their own, and certainly not at a constant rate.   Connected to that second point, if a member of Congress wants a bill passed, but it's scope is far beyond their own office's resources, they will bring it to party leadership. Leadership might just take the idea and lump it in with something else they're working on, maybe they'll write up a whole bill from scratch. Either way, it gets that leadership person's name on it.   So the short answer is that those leadership folks aren't coming up with all the ideas, but their offices have the resources to put together an actual bill from an idea.
